{{EngvarB|date=March 2019}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Conor Coady | image = Conor Coady.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Coady training for [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] during the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] | fullname = Conor David Coady<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |title=Premier League Clubs submit Squad Lists |publisher=Premier League |format=PDF |page=19 |date=4 February 2014 |accessdate=11 February 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316063138/http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |archivedate=16 March 2014}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|2|25|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/4136/Conor-Coady/overview |title=Conor Coady: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Liverpool]], England | height = {{convert|1.86|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/team/first-team/conor-coady/ |title=Conor Coady |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | clubnumber = 16 | youthyears1 = 2005–2013 |youthclubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool]] | years1 = 2012–2014 |clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |caps1 = 1 |goals1 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years2 = 2013–2014 |clubs2 = → [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] (loan) |caps2 = 39 |goals2 = 5<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years3 = 2014–2015 |clubs3 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] |caps3 = 45 |goals3 = 3<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years4 = 2015– |clubs4 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps4 = 148 |goals4 = 1<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | nationalyears1 = 2009 |nationalteam1=[[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalcaps1 = 4 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2009–2010|nationalteam2=[[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 17 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2011|nationalteam3=[[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] |nationalcaps3 = 2 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2011 |nationalteam4=[[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] |nationalcaps4 = 12 |nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2013 |nationalteam5=[[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps5 = 4 |nationalgoals5 = 1 | club-update = 00:07, 12 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Conor David Coady''' (born 25 February 1993) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].
Coady came through the academy system at his local club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and made two appearances for the first team before spending a season on loan at [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] and then moving to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a permanent transfer in 2014. He has also represented England at youth level, being named in the team of the tournament as England won the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] and captaining the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]] team at the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2013 under-20 World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Liverpool=== Born in [[Liverpool]],<ref>{{Hugman|22610|accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> Coady grew up supporting [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref name="liverpool supporter">{{cite web |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheff-utd/sheffield-united-conor-would-be-keen-on-lane-option-1-6591466 |title=Conor would be keen on Lane option |publisher=The Sheffield Star |date=2 May 2014 |accessdate=2 May 2014}}</ref> He is a product of the [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool Youth Academy]] after joining the club in 2005. During the [[2010–11 Liverpool F.C. season|2010–11 season]], Coady was on the fringes of the first team, making the subs bench twice but failed to make a first-team appearance.<ref>{{cite web |last=Whyatt |first=Chris |title=Sparta Prague 0 – 0 Liverpool |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/9399199.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 March 2013 |date=17 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Dawkes |first=Phil |title=Liverpool 9 – 1 Birmingham |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9463392.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 March 2013 |date=23 April 2011}}</ref> Coady played every [[Barclays Premier Reserve League|Reserve League]] and [[NextGen Series]] match during the [[2011–12 Liverpool F.C. season|2011–12 season]], scoring five goals. Despite being named in the senior squad list and being called up to the senior squad occasionally from 2009, he did not make his senior début until 8 November 2012 in a [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Anzhi Makhachkala]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20164149 |title=Anzhi Makhachkala 1–0 Liverpool |date=8 November 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> After [[Andre Wisdom]]'s promotion as a full-time senior squad member, Conor Coady was installed as full-time captain of the Under-21 squad and on 12 May 2013 he made his Premier League début in a 3–1 win at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Seven starlets who stepped up in 2012–13 |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/seven-starlets-who-stepped-up-in-2012-13 |publisher=Liverpool FC |accessdate=23 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402152829/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/seven-starlets-who-stepped-up-in-2012-13 |archivedate=2 April 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Coady agreed a six-month loan deal with [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on 22 July 2013,<ref name="blades loan">{{cite web |url=http://www.sufc.co.uk/news/article/20130722-coady-in-on-loan-936404.aspx |title=Coady in on loan |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=22 July 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013}}</ref> later stating that he had turned down the chance to go on Liverpool's pre-season tour of Australia and the Far East in order to join up with his new club.<ref name="Rodgers influence">{{cite news |title=Coady reveals Rodgers influence |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11683/8836859/coady-reveals-rodgers-infleunce |accessdate=23 July 2013 |publisher=Sky Sports News |date=23 July 2013}}</ref> Coady made his debut for the Blades in the opening fixture of the following season, coming on as a second-half substitute in a 2–1 home victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]],<ref name="blades debut">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/aug/02/sheffield-united-notts-county-report |title=Sheffield United's David Weir off to winning start against Notts County |work=The Guardian |date=2 August 2013 |accessdate=3 August 2013}}</ref> and made his first start for the club in the following game, a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] first round defeat to [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23499353 |title=Sheffield United 1–2 Burton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 August 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
Coady scored his first senior goal in a 1–1 draw at [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 30 November 2013.<ref name="blades goal">{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/288435/report |title=Cox snatches point for Orient |publisher=Sky Sports |date=30 November 2013 |accessdate=2 December 2013}}</ref> Having been in and out of the team during the first half of the season, Coady began to cement a regular first-team place over the Christmas period, prompting United to extend his loan spell during the January transfer window,<ref name="blades loan extension">{{cite news |title=Liverpool youngster Conor Coady extends loan spell with Sheffield United |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-youngster-conor-coady-extends-3001910 |accessdate=10 January 2014 |work=Daily Mirror |date=8 January 2014}}</ref> and once more in February to extend his stay until the end of the season.<ref name="coady end season">{{cite news |title=Liverpool midfielder extends Sheffield United loan deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26338499 |accessdate=25 February 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2014}}</ref> Coady played regularly for the Blades for the remainder of the season and returned to [[Anfield]] having played 50 games and scored six goals.<ref name="1314apps">{{Soccerbase season|58424|2013|name=Conor Coady|accessdate=11 May 2014}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 6 August 2014, Coady signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a three-year deal for a fee, believed to be around £500,000.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Conor Coady Joins Huddersfield Town |url=http://www.htafc.com/news/article/first-team-news-conor-coady-1809298.aspx |publisher=Huddersfield Town F.C |date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> He made his début as a substitute in the 4–0 defeat by [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on 9 August.<ref name="stats"/> On 1 October, he scored his first goal for the club against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] where Town won 3–1 at [[Molineux Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Huddersfield Town earned a surprise win away at Wolves to stop the hosts going top of the Championship. |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29338891 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> He again found the net, this time in a 2–2 draw against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Rotherham United 2 Huddersfield Town 2 |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/30543342 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== [[File:Coady Ralls.jpg|thumbnail|Coady (left) defending against [[Joe Ralls]].]]
On 3 July 2015, Coady signed for Championship club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a three-year deal for an undisclosed fee, believed to be around £2 million.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Conor Coady: Wolves sign Huddersfield Town midfielder |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33380799 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 July 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Wolves in a 2–1 [[EFL Cup]] win against [[Crawley Town]] on 9 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36949401 |title=Wolves 2–1 Crawley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2016 |accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref>
As of the start of the 2017–18 season, Coady has, at the behest of Wolves' manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]], played at centre-half in a three-man defence for Wolves.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/09/22/delighted-conor-coady-signs-four-year-wolves-contract/ |title=Delighted Conor Coady signs four-year Wolves contract |work=[[Express & Star]] |date=22 September 2017 |accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
It was announced in September 2017 that Coady had signed a new four-year contract with Wolves, running until summer 2021.<ref>{{cite news |title=Four more years! |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20170922-four-more-years/ |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C |date=22 September 2017}}</ref>
On 21 April 2018, during his 120th league appearance for Wolves, Coady scored a 66th minute penalty in a 4–0 win against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] to get his first league goal for the club, as Wolves sealed the [[EFL Championship]] title.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bolton Wanderers 0–4 Wolves |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43762334 |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=21 April 2018}}</ref>
It was announced on 15 February 2019 that Coady had put pen to paper on a new contract that would keep him at Wolverhampton Wanderers until the summer of 2023.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wolves: Conor Coady and Matt Doherty sign new deals until 2023 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47260570 |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=15 February 2019 |accessdate=16 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Coady has represented England at Under-16 right through to Under-20 level.<ref name="FA">{{cite web |title=The FA profile |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/C/Conor-Coady |publisher=The FA |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> He has been capped 17 times for the [[England national under-17 football team]].<ref name="FA"/> He played and captained<ref>{{cite web |title=England U-17s beat Spain to win European Championship |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8713980.stm |publisher=BBC |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref> the England team at the [[2010 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]] in Liechtenstein where he and his England colleagues won the tournament, and became the first England team to win an international tournament in 17 years.<ref name="win">{{cite web |last=Rice |first=Jimmy |title=Wisdom scores in historic triumph |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/wisdom-scores-in-historic-triumph |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=9 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402152924/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/wisdom-scores-in-historic-triumph |archivedate=2 April 2015 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He was then part of the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] in Estonia<ref>{{cite web |last=Rice |first=Jimmy |title=LFC duo named in U19s Euro squad |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/lfc-duo-named-in-u19s-euro-squad |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=9 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904141407/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/lfc-duo-named-in-u19s-euro-squad |archivedate=4 September 2012}}</ref> in which England got as far as the semi-finals where they were knocked out by [[Greece national under-19 football team|Greece]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Hunter |first=Steve |title=Final joy for Suso as England lose |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/final-joy-for-suso-as-england-lose |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=9 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026185722/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/final-joy-for-suso-as-england-lose |archivedate=26 October 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He was named captain of the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] by manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer born 1953)|Peter Taylor]] for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/conor-coady-to-captain-young-lions-fifa-world-cup |title=Captain Coady |publisher=The Football Association |date=11 June 2013 |accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> He made his debut for the team on 16 June, in a 3–0 win in a warm-up game against [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130624222816/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=24 June 2013 |title=England U20s continue World Cup preparations with a 3–0 win over Uruguay |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 June 2013 |accessdate=17 June 2013}}</ref> On 23 June, he scored in the opening group-stage game against [[Iraq national under-20 football team|Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/iraq-updates-230613 |title=England v Iraq |publisher=The Football Association |date=23 June 2013 |accessdate=24 June 2013}}</ref>

{{About||the Spanish footballer|Jota (footballer)|the other Portuguese footballer also known as Jota|João Filipe (Portuguese footballer)}} {{Portuguese name|Teixeira|Silva}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Diogo Jota |image = |image_size = |caption = |fullname = Diogo José Teixeira da Silva<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127|title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=3 September 2018|accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|12|4|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Porto]], Portugal |height = 1.78 m |position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] |currentclub = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |clubnumber = 18 |youthyears1 = 2005–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Gondomar S.C.|Gondomar]] |youthyears2 = 2013–2015 | youthclubs2 = [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira|Paços Ferreira]] |years1 = 2014–2016 | clubs1 = [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira|Paços Ferreira]] | caps1 = 41 | goals1 = 14 |years2 = 2016–2018 | clubs2 = [[Atlético Madrid]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = → [[FC Porto|Porto]] (loan) | caps3 = 27 | goals3 = 8 |years4 = 2017–2018 | clubs4 = → [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] (loan) | caps4 = 44 | goals4 = 17 |years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps5 = 25 | goals5 = 6 |nationalyears1 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 9 | nationalgoals1 = 5 |nationalyears2 = 2015–2018 | nationalteam2 = [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portugal U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 20 | nationalgoals2 = 8 |nationalyears3 = 2016 | nationalteam3 = [[Portugal Olympic football team|Portugal U23]] | nationalcaps3 = 1 | nationalgoals3 = 1 |club-update = 16:41, 19 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = 20 November 2018 }} '''Diogo José Teixeira da Silva''' (born 4 December 1996), known as '''Diogo Jota''', is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].
He started playing with [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira|Paços de Ferreira]], signing with [[Atlético Madrid]] after two seasons in the [[Primeira Liga]] and being consecutively loaned to [[FC Porto|Porto]] and Wolverhampton Wanderers. In 2018, he moved to the latter club on a permanent deal.
Jota played for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] at [[Portugal national under-19 football team|under-19]], [[Portugal national under-21 football team|under-21]] and [[Portugal Olympic football team|under-23 levels]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/liga/fc-porto/portugal-sub-20-andre-horta-e-diogo-jota-convocados-para-estagio|title=Portugal (sub-20): André Horta e Diogo Jota convocados para estágio|trans-title=Portugal (under-20): André Horta and Diogo Jota called for training camp|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=22 January 2016|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.pt/futebol/selecoes/selecao-olimpica/detalhe/portugal-mexico-em-direto.html|title=Portugal-México, 4–0|trans-title=Portugal-Mexico, 4–0|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=pt|date=28 March 2016|accessdate=7 June 2018|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612142517/http://www.record.pt/futebol/selecoes/selecao-olimpica/detalhe/portugal-mexico-em-direto.html|archive-date=12 June 2018|df=}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Paços Ferreira=== Born in [[Massarelos]], [[Porto]], Jota joined [[F.C. Paços de Ferreira]]'s youth setup in 2013, from [[Gondomar S.C.|Gondomar SC]]. He was promoted to the main squad at the start of the [[2014–15 Primeira Liga|2014–15 season]], and made his senior debut on 19 October 2014 by starting in a [[2014–15 Taça de Portugal|4–0 home win]] against [[Atlético S.C.]] for the [[Taça de Portugal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/nacional/1a-liga/pacos-ferreira/detalhe/jota-tera-mais-oportunidades-924946.html|title=Jota terá mais oportunidades|trans-title=Jota will have more opportunities|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=13 January 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://archive.today/20160316090427/http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/nacional/1a-liga/pacos-ferreira/detalhe/jota-tera-mais-oportunidades-924946.html|archive-date=16 March 2016}}</ref>
Jota first appeared in the [[Primeira Liga]] on 20 February 2015, coming on as a late [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Diogo Rosado]] in a 2–2 home draw against [[Vitória S.C.|Vitória de Guimarães]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcpf.pt/PagFutebol-noticias-pacos-e-vitoria-empatam-2-2-em-relvado-encharcado|title=Paços e Vitória empatam (2–2) em relvado encharcado|trans-title=Paços and Vitória draw (2–2) in waterlogged pitch|publisher=F.C. Paços Ferreira|language=pt|date=20 February 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goals in the competition on 17 May, netting a brace in a 3–2 home success over [[Associação Académica de Coimbra – O.A.F.|Académica de Coimbra]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcpf.pt/noticias-pacos-vence-academica-e-deixa-sonho-a-um-ponto|title=Paços vence Académica e deixa sonho a um ponto|trans-title=Paços defeat Académica and keep dream a point away|publisher=F.C. Paços Ferreira|language=pt|date=17 May 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref> and becoming the youngest player to score for the club in the top tier in the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcpf.pt/noticias-diogo-jota-e-o-mais-jovem-a-marcar-pelo-pacos-na-i-liga|title=Diogo Jota é o mais jovem a marcar pelo Paços na I Liga|trans-title=Diogo Jota is the youngest to score for Paços in I League|publisher=F.C. Paços Ferreira|language=pt|date=19 May 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>
On 30 May 2015, Jota signed a new five-year deal with Paços, keeping him tied up until 2020.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/nacional/1a-liga/pacos-ferreira/detalhe/jota-seguro-ate-2020-951755.html|title=Jota seguro até 2020|trans-title=Jota secured until 2020|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=30 May 2015|accessdate=31 October 2015|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://archive.today/20160316090357/http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/nacional/1a-liga/pacos-ferreira/detalhe/jota-seguro-ate-2020-951755.html|archive-date=16 March 2016}}</ref> In the first game of [[2015–16 Primeira Liga|the campaign]], a 1–0 win over Académica at the ''[[Estádio da Mata Real]]'' on 17 August, he was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] at the end for pushing [[Hugo Seco]]; [[Ricardo Nascimento (Brazilian footballer)|Ricardo Nascimento]] was also sent off for retaliating on his teammate's behalf.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://desporto.sapo.pt/futebol/primeira_liga/epoca-1516/jogos/191532?id=hFwzCYiuwL9cc5gzPmOo|title=P. Ferreira 1–0 Académica|publisher=[[SAPO (company)|SAPO]]|language=pt|date=17 August 2015|accessdate=12 April 2016}}</ref>
===Atlético Madrid=== On 14 March 2016, Jota agreed a five-year contract with [[Atlético Madrid]] effective as of 1 July.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/futbol/atletico/2016/03/14/56e70d3546163fd3718b45c3.html|title=El Atlético ficha a Diogo Jota|trans-title=Atlético sign Diogo Jota|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=es|date=14 March 2016|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> On 26 August, however, he returned to his country and joined [[FC Porto]] on a one-year loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/pt/noticias/Pages/diogo-jota-no-dragao-para-reforcar-ataque.aspx|title=Diogo Jota no Dragão para reforçar o ataque|trans-title=Diogo Jota to the Dragão to bolster the attack|publisher=FC Porto|language=pt|date=26 August 2016|access-date=26 August 2016}}</ref> On 1 October he scored a first-half [[hat-trick (association football)|hat-trick]] in a 4–0 away victory against [[C.D. Nacional]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sabado.pt/desporto/futebol/detalhe/fc_porto_goleia_nacional_com_hat_trick_de_diogo_jota.html|title=FC Porto goleia Nacional com 'hat-trick' de Diogo Jota|trans-title=FC Porto rout Nacional with Diogo Jota 'hat-trick'|magazine=[[Sábado (magazine)|Sábado]]|language=pt|date=1 October 2016|accessdate=2 October 2016}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 25 July 2017, Jota moved to [[EFL Championship|English Championship]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a [[2017–18 EFL Championship|season]]-long loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40715875|title=Diogo Jota: Atletico Madrid midfielder joins Wolves on season-long loan|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 July 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal on 15 August, in a 3–2 away win over [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40858331|title=Hull City 2–3 Wolverhampton Wanderers|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2017|accessdate=16 August 2017}}</ref>
On 30 January 2018, it was announced that a permanent deal with Jota had been agreed, being made effective on 1 July.<ref name=ToWolves>{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180130-permanent-deal-for-jota-agreed/|title=Permanent deal for Jota agreed|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C|date=30 January 2018|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> He scored a career-best 17 goals in his first year, ranking fifth in the individual charts in a [[Premier League]] promotion as champions;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/693584|title=FPL promotion prospects: The Wolves worth hunting|publisher=[[Premier League]]|date=27 May 2018|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> due to [[English Football League]] regulations, he wore his legal surname on his [[Kit (association football)|jersey]] in the Championship but was able to change it to "Diogo J" after the feat.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2018/08/10/rui-patricio-honours-carl-ikeme-as-wolves-reveal-new-kit-numbers/|title=Rui Patricio honours Carl Ikeme as Wolves reveal new kit numbers|newspaper=[[Express & Star]]|last=Hatfield|first=Luke|date=10 August 2018|accessdate=29 August 2018}}</ref>
Jota made his debut in the [[English football league system|English top division]] on 11 August 2018, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–2 home draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45067374|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–2 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Hafez|first=Shamoon|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal in the competition on 5 December, helping the hosts come from behind to beat [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46367295|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–1 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Emons|first=Michael|date=5 December 2018|accessdate=5 December 2018}}</ref> His second came four days later, in a win at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] by the same scoreline.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46416287|title=Newcastle 1–2 Wolves: Visitors score 95th-minute winner against 10 men|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Sanders|first=Emma|date=9 December 2018|accessdate=10 December 2018}}</ref>
On 19 January 2019, Jota netted three times in the 4–3 home defeat of [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] – his second career hat-trick.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46847686|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 4–3 Leicester City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Reddy|first=Luke|date=19 January 2019|accessdate=19 January 2019}}</ref> In the process, he became only the second Portuguese player to achieve the feat in the Premier League after [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] 11 years earlier.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maisfutebol.iol.pt/made-in/internacional/diogo-jota-e-o-2-portugues-a-fazer-um-hat-trick-na-premier-league|title=Diogo Jota é o 2.º português a fazer um hat-trick na Premier League|trans-title=Diogo Jota is the 2nd Portuguese to score hat-trick in the Premier League|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=19 January 2019|accessdate=19 January 2019}}</ref> This was a first-ever for the club in the competition and a first for the club in the [[English football league system|top flight of English football]] since [[John Richards (footballer)|John Richards]], against the same opposition, in the [[Football League First Division]] in [[1977–78 in English football|October 1977]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sport.bt.com/news/jota-basks-in-the-joy-of-wolves-first-top-flight-treble-for-42-years-S11364328553266|title=Jota basks in the joy of Wolves’ first top-flight treble for 42 years|publisher=[[BT Sport]]|date=20 January 2019|accessdate=20 January 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Jota started playing for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] at [[Portugal national under-19 football team|under-19 level]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/internacional/selecao/noticias/interior/sub-19-yuri-ribeiro-rui-silva-e-jota-chamados-4139049.html|title=Sub-19: Yuri Ribeiro, Rui Silva e Jota chamados|trans-title=Under-19: Yuri Ribeiro, Rui Silva and Jota called|newspaper=[[O Jogo]]|language=pt|date=22 September 2014|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> scoring his first goal on 29 May 2015 in a 6–1 home routing of [[Turkey national under-19 football team|Turkey]] for the [[2015 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|UEFA European Championship]] [[2015 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|qualifying phase]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/selecao/turquia/sub-19-portugal-comeca-qualificacao-com-goleada|title=Sub-19: Portugal começa qualificação com goleada|trans-title=Under-19: Portugal start qualification with routing|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=29 May 2015|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref> He won his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] for [[Portugal national under-21 football team|the under-21 team]] on 17 November of the same year at not yet 19, playing 15 minutes in the 3–0 away defeat of [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Israel]] in [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|another qualifier]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/selecao/rui-jorge/sub-21-israel-portugal-0-3-cronica|title=Sub-21: Israel-Portugal, 0–3 (crónica)|trans-title=Under-21: Israel-Portugal, 0–3 (match report)|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=17 November 2015|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>
On 25 May 2018, Jota netted a brace for the under-21s in their 3–2 [[Exhibition game|friendly]] win over [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy]] held in [[Estoril]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dn.pt/lusa/interior/selecao-portuguesa-de-sub-21-vence-italia-por-3-2-em-jogo-de-preparacao-9379316.html|title=Seleção portuguesa de sub-21 vence Itália por 3–2 em jogo de preparação|trans-title=Under-21 Portuguese national team beat Italy 3–2 in friendly match|newspaper=[[Diário de Notícias]]|language=pt|date=25 May 2018|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>
In March 2019, Jota was called up to the senior side for the first time, ahead of the opening [[UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying]] matches.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jota earns senior Portugal call-up|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/club/20190318-jota-earns-senior-portugal-call-up/|date=19 March 2019|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.}}</ref>

[[Jon]] | derivation = | meaning = | variant = [[Johnny]] [[Jonnie]] [[Jonathan (name)|Jonathan]] [[Jon]] | shortform = | petname = | cognate = | anglicisation = | derivative = | wikt = }} '''Jonny''' is a masculine [[given name]], and [[pet name]], in the [[English language]]. A pet form of [[Jon]], the natural diminutive of given name [[Jonathan (name)|Jonathan]], in some cases it can also be a simplified form of ''[[Johnny (personal name)|Johnny]]''; in other cases it is a pet form of ''[[Jon]]''. A variant form of ''Jonny'' is ''[[Jonnie]]''.{{citation |last1=Hanks |first1=Patrick |last2=Hardcastle |authorlink1=Patrick Hanks |first2=Kate |last3=Hodges |first3=Flavia |title=A Dictionary of First Names |edition=2nd |series=Oxford Paperback Reference |year=2006 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |location=[[Oxford]] |isbn=978-0-19-861060-1 |page=147 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{given name|cat=none}} [[Category:English-language masculine given names]]

|nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 23:17, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:17, 2 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''John Thomas Gordon Ruddy''' (born 24 October 1986) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|WolverhW}} club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].
Ruddy began his career at [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]], before signing for [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] as a 19-year-old. He spent five years with Everton, but made just one appearance, while playing on loan at nine different clubs. Ruddy was signed by [[Paul Lambert]] to play for [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in 2010 and, in his first season, was part of the team that finished second in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], gaining promotion to the Premier League.
The following year, Norwich finished twelfth in the Premier League, and Ruddy was selected by new England manager [[Roy Hodgson]] for the squad for [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]]. However, on 25 May 2012, he was ruled out after breaking his finger during training. He made his debut in a 2–1 win against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in August 2012. He suffered a long term thigh injury in November 2012, but returned to help Norwich to an 11th-place finish at the end of the [[2012–13 Premier League]] season. After 243 appearances for Norwich, he moved to Wolverhampton Wanderers in 2017.
==Club career== ===Cambridge United=== Born in [[St Ives, Cambridgeshire]],<ref name=Hugman0910/> Ruddy began his career at [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] and made his professional debut in the final match of the 2003–04 season at [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]]'s [[Brisbane Road]] stadium on 8 May 2004, keeping a [[clean sheet]] and saving a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Ruddy earned his place as Cambridge's first choice keeper in the 2004–05 season, making 38 appearances in a season that saw the U's relegated from league two after finishing bottom with 30 points.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/league-two/2004-2005 |title=English League Two 2004–2005 Table |publisher=Statto Organisation |accessdate=19 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428130211/http://www.statto.com/football/stats/england/league-two/2004-2005 |archivedate=28 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This was despite Ruddy's tremendous efforts, which included keeping 9 clean sheets and conceding just 45 goals.<ref name=sb0405/>
===Everton=== Ruddy had a trial at [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in November 2004, before moving to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in the summer of 2005 for a fee of around £250,000 that would rise depending on appearances.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/e/everton/4565337.stm |title=Ruddy completes Goodison switch |date=20 May 2005 |accessdate=17 May 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Ruddy was called into the England Under-19 squad in 2005 after being scouted by England goalkeeping coach [[Ray Clemence]] and was touted by his manager [[David Moyes]] as a future England goalkeeper.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
In September 2005, Ruddy signed for [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/ruddy-s-walsall-loan-move.html |title=Ruddy's Walsall loan move |publisher=Everton F.C. |accessdate=17 May 2012 |date=23 September 2005 |first=Scott |last=McLeod}}</ref> making four appearances in [[EFL League One|League One]] before returning to Everton.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Loan spells with [[Rushden & Diamonds F.C.|Rushden & Diamonds]] and [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]] followed.<ref name=rush>{{cite web |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/ruddy-switches-to-stockport.html |title=Ruddy switches to Stockport |accessdate=17 May 2012 |date=12 September 2006 |publisher=Everton F.C.}}</ref>
Ruddy made his first and only appearance for Everton in February 2006 in unusual circumstances. Nine minutes into the match against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], [[Iain Turner]] was sent off for handling outside the area. Since Turner was substituting for injured first- and second-choice keepers [[Nigel Martyn]] and [[Richard Wright (footballer)|Richard Wright]], it meant that Ruddy was the only keeper left who could play. Ruddy went on to keep a clean sheet in a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/4680522.stm|title=Everton 1–0 Blackburn|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 February 2006|accessdate=15 March 2011}}</ref>
In September 2006, Ruddy went on loan again. A one-month deal was agreed with [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]],<ref name=rush/> which was extended to three months after some impressive performances.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He then agreed a one-month loan with [[Wrexham A.F.C.|Wrexham]] in February 2007,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11671_2405198,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Wrexham hire Ruddy |first=Lewis |last=Rutledge |accessdate=17 May 2012}}</ref> but failed to establish a place in the team during his time at the Racecourse Ground and the Red Dragons decided against extending the loan beyond the initial month.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} On 21 April 2007, Ruddy completed an emergency one-week loan to League One club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10327~1014027,00.html |publisher=Bristol City F.C. |accessdate=17 May 2012 |title=Ruddy solves keeping crisis |date=22 April 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221231955/http://www.bcfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10327~1014027%2C00.html |archivedate=21 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> and helped them move closer to promotion, by playing one match – a 3–1 win over [[Carlisle United F.C|Carlisle United]], and later joked he would ask if he were eligible for a runners-up medal as City finished second and won promotion.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} In January 2009, he went out on loan until the end of the 2008–09 season to [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/ruddy-joins-crewe.html |publisher=Everton F.C. |accessdate=17 May 2012 |title=Ruddy joins Crewe |date=29 January 2009}}</ref>
===Motherwell=== On 24 July 2009, Ruddy joined [[Scottish Premier League]] club [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] on a six-month loan deal, to vie with [[Michael Fraser (footballer)|Michael Fraser]] and Sebastian Kosiorowski for a place in goal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/motherwell/8168189.stm|title=Well sign Everton keeper on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009}}</ref> Ruddy kept clean sheets during a 0–0 home draw against Rangers on 12 September 2009 and a 0–0 away draw against Celtic on 17 October 2009.<ref name=Soccerway/> He also saved a Barry Robson penalty in a 3–2 loss to Celtic on 12 December 2009.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} When the original loan deal expired in January 2010, the Fir Park club decided that they wanted to keep Ruddy for longer and an extension of a month was agreed with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} On 27 January 2010, it was announced that both Ruddy and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] teammate [[Lukas Jutkiewicz]] were to extend their stay at the Scottish Premier League club until May 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/duo-extend-loans-until-may.html|title=Duo Extend Loans Until May|publisher=Everton F.C.|date=27 January 2010}}</ref> Ruddy finished the Scottish Premier League season with 15 clean sheets from 34 appearances.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
===Norwich City=== [[File:Ruddy.JPG|thumb|upright|Ruddy celebrating [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]'s promotion into the [[Premier League]] in 2011]]
On 5 July 2010, Ruddy signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] for an undisclosed fee, which Ruddy revealed in 2017 to have been £250,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39843745|title=John Ruddy: Norwich City goalkeeper not surprised by release from Carrow Road|date=8 May 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In 2012, [[Paul Lambert]] revealed that on two earlier occasions he had considered signing Ruddy for clubs he'd previously managed: "It is funny but ... [I] ... went to watch him for Crewe at MK Dons ... but he had an absolute stinker. We also saw him when he was at Stockport and ... I decided against him at that time, but when [[Fraser Forster|Fraser]] went and it was clear we wouldn't be able to get him back again I knew John had had a really good season at Motherwell. There was that clamour to sign Fraser, but with the finances we just couldn't do that. I wanted somebody with the same stature, a big goalkeeper, and John had that."<ref>{{cite news|title=Fraser Forster is top class – Norwich City goalkeeper John Ruddy|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/fraser_forster_is_top_class_norwich_city_goalkeeper_john_ruddy_1_1408885|newspaper=Eastern Daily Press |location=Norwich|date=13 June 2012|accessdate=26 December 2012}}</ref>
Ruddy made his debut for City against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in the opening fixture of the [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11 season]] which Norwich lost 3–2 at [[Carrow Road]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8880936.stm|title=Norwich 2–3 Watford|date=6 August 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2011}}</ref> He kept his first clean sheet of the season in a 1–0 away win against [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] on 14 August 2010, following this up with another clean sheet against Swansea on 21 August 2010 which included a penalty save that atoned for his error that led to it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8918635.stm |title=Norwich 2–0 Swansea |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2010 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> In Ruddy's first season for Norwich, he played 45 out of the 46 league matches, helping City to the [[Premier League]], keeping a clean sheet during the 1–0 away win against Portsmouth on 2 May 2011 which sealed promotion for the Canaries.<ref>{{cite news |last=Fletcher |first=Paul |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13185001 |title=Norwich seal Premier League place |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2011 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
Ruddy started the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]] as the first choice keeper again for Norwich, starting the 1–1 draw at the [[DW Stadium]] against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14429588.stm|title=Wigan 1–1 Norwich|date=13 August 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2011}}</ref> He followed this up by making numerous good saves during Norwich's first home premier league match in seven years in a 1–1 draw against Stoke, including a penalty stop against Jon Walters and a save denying Matthew Etherington from a direct free kick.<ref>{{cite news |last=Roberts |first=Gareth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14520268 |title=Norwich 1–1 Stoke |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> During the next match, he received his only red card of the season in the match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] after a foul on [[Ramires]] that led to a penalty.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14600575.stm|title=Chelsea 3–1 Norwich|date=27 August 2011|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=17 September 2011}}</ref> However, Ruddy's fortunes were reversed during the return fixture against Chelsea on 21 January 2012 when he kept his first clean sheet of the season during a 0–0 draw at Carrow Road, making several impressive stops from Fernando Torres.<ref>{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Owen |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16559646 |title=Norwich 0–0 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> Ruddy was voted Player's Player of the Season following Norwich's 12th-place finish,<ref name=fa>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/News/2012/john-ruddy-norwich-euro-2012-call-up-wedding |title=Ruddy's big summer |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202150206/http://www.thefa.com/England/News/2012/john-ruddy-norwich-euro-2012-call-up-wedding |archivedate=2 February 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> this was a testament to Ruddy's performances for a highly attacking Norwich team, leading to suggestions that he should be called up for Roy Hodgson's England Euro 2012 squad.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/n/norwich/9622844.stm |title=Norwich boss Lambert leads the 'Ruddy for England' calls |accessdate=17 May 2012 |date=24 October 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Ruddy's claim for a squad place was only strengthened by his excellent performance during the 2–0 home win against Aston Villa on the final day of the season.<ref>{{cite news |last=Darling |first=Kevin |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17973120 |title=Norwich 2–0 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 May 2012 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
For the 2012–13 season Ruddy found himself first choice again ahead of [[Declan Rudd]], [[Jed Steer]] and new goalie [[Mark Bunn (English footballer)|Mark Bunn]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Once again, he saved a penalty during Norwich's first home Premier League fixture of the season during a 1–1 draw with Queens Park Rangers, although [[Bobby Zamora]] scored the rebound.<ref>{{cite news |last=Osborne |first=Chris |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19304497 |title=Norwich 1–1 QPR |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> He kept memorable clean sheets against Arsenal and Manchester United as Norwich won 1–0 on both occasions, both occurring during an outstanding run of form that saw him keep four clean sheets and concede just two goals in six matches.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Unfortunately this great run of form came to an end during a 1–1 draw against his former club Everton when he suffered a thigh injury.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He later underwent surgery, ruling him out for three months.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hughton dealt injury blow as first choice goalkeeper Ruddy is ruled out for three months|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2239947/John-Ruddy-ruled-months.html|newspaper=Daily Mail|location=London|date=28 November 2012|accessdate=26 December 2012}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> However, Ruddy's injury later worsened, with the expectation that he would not be fit again until April.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City: John Ruddy muscle 'ripped off bone'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21078118|publisher=BBC|date=18 January 2013|accessdate=19 January 2013}}</ref> Ruddy returned to action on 7 May 2013 in Norwich's 4–0 Premier League win over West Bromwich Albion, which confirmed mathematical safety from relegation.<ref>{{cite news |last=Chase |first=Graham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22417730 |title= Norwich 4–0 West Brom |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2013 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> He also played in Norwich's final match of the season on 19 May 2013, a 3–2 away win against Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shemilt |first=Stephan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22499159 |title=Man City 2–3 Norwich |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 May 2013 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
Despite the previous long term injury, Ruddy started the 2013–14 season as Norwich's first choice keeper in the 2–2 draw with Everton at Carrow Road on 17 August 2013.<ref>{{cite news |last=Phillips |first=Owen |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23644749 |title=Norwich 2–2 Everton |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> Ruddy had a tough start to the season which included mistake riddled performances against Spurs,<ref>{{cite news |last=Reddy |first=Luke |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23999467 |title=Tottenham 2–0 Norwich |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> Chelsea<ref>{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Gary |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24350208 |title=Norwich City 1–3 Chelsea |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> and Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Gary |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24681355 |title=Manchester City 7–0 Norwich City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 November 2013 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> However, since the 5–1 away thrashing at Liverpool<ref>{{cite news |last=Henson |first=Mike |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/25115744 |title=Liverpool 5–1 Norwich City |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> Ruddy has been in fine form keeping four clean sheets in nine matches, conceding just seven goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/norwich-city/results |title=Norwich City Results |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 April 2016}}</ref> During this spell Ruddy produced some outstanding performances, including the 2–0 away win against West Bromwich Albion on 7 December 2013 where he saved eight shots, including a brilliant tip around the post from a close range Shane Long header.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25164355 |title=West Bromwich Albion 0–2 Norwich City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2013 |accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref>
In May 2017, it was announced that Ruddy would be released when his contract expired.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39780816 |title=Norwich City: John Ruddy & Sebastien Bassong among seven released by Canaries |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2017 |accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref> All the players who were being released were given the option of whether or not they chose to be available for selection in the one remaining match of the season. In the end, Ruddy was the only one of the seven who played in the match, being made team captain for the day (he had previously captained the side for one match in the 2013–14 season when [[Sébastien Bassong]] and [[Russell Martin (footballer)|Russell Martin]] were both absent) and saw out his time with the club by keeping a clean sheet in a 4–0 win over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city/john-ruddy-thankful-for-his-opportunity-to-enjoy-a-fantastic-farewell-appearance-for-norwich-city-1-5006782|title=Norwich City: John Ruddy thankful for his opportunity to enjoy a 'fantastic' farewell appearance for Norwich City |newspaper=Eastern Daily Press |location=Norwich |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 10 July 2017, Ruddy signed a two-year contract with Championship club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20170710-wolves-snap-up-experienced-keeper/ |title=Wolves snap up experienced 'keeper |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |date=10 July 2017 |accessdate=10 July 2017}}</ref> His signing came days after the club's previous number one [[Carl Ikeme]] was diagnosed with acute leukaemia.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/wolves-goalkeeper-carl-ikeme-diagnosed-10750504|title=Wolves goalkeeper Carl Ikeme diagnosed with acute leukaemia|last=Domin|first=Martin|date=6 July 2017|newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=10 July 2017}}</ref> On 6 April 2018, Ruddy saved an injury time penalty from [[Gary Madine]] away at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in a 1–0 win, in a victory that took Wolves nine points clear of Cardiff.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/06/wolves-survive-two-injury-time-cardiff-penalties-edge-closer/|title=Wolves survive two injury-time Cardiff penalties to edge closer to Championship title|publisher=Telegraph|date=6 April 2018|accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref> Ruddy became the team's main goalkeeper and was part of the team that won promotion to the Premier League as champions. He was named in the division's PFA Team of the Year<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43810017 |title=Manchester City players dominate PFA team of the year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 April 2018}}</ref> and was awarded the EFL's Golden Glove Award for the most clean sheets with 24.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11699/11351528/wolves-john-ruddy-wins-championship-golden-glove-award|title=Wolves' John Ruddy wins Championship Golden Glove award |publisher=Sky Sports |date=28 April 2018}}</ref>
In August 2018 he extended his contract with Wolves, signing a deal due to last until summer 2020, despite having fallen behind new addition [[Rui Patrício]] as the club's first-choice goalkeeper.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180831-ruddy-extends-molineux-stay/ |title=Ruddy extends Molineux stay |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |date=31 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== On 16 May 2012, Ruddy received his first senior international call-up when [[Roy Hodgson]] selected him as a member of the [[England national football team|England]] squad for [[UEFA Euro 2012]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Norwich City's John Ruddy named in England's Euro 2012 squad, but Grant Holt misses out|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/norwich_city_s_john_ruddy_named_in_england_s_euro_2012_squad_but_grant_holt_misses_out_1_1379272 |newspaper=Eastern Daily Press |location=Norwich |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012}}</ref> However, a broken finger ruled him out of the tournament, and [[Jack Butland]] was called up to replace him.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Ruddy was called up for the friendly against Italy in [[Bern]], Switzerland, on 10 August 2012, along with Butland and [[Joe Hart]].{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He came on for Butland at half-time to make his senior England debut, and made some key saves as England won the match 2–1, keeping a clean sheet in his first England appearance after Butland conceded in the first half.<ref>{{cite news |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |title=England 2–1 Italy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19238374 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2012 |accessdate=18 August 2012}}</ref>
Ruddy was not included in Hodgson's World Cup squad, with Joe Hart, [[Fraser Forster]] and [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]] selected instead.<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2014: England name Ross Barkley in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27362447 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2014 |accessdate=17 April 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Ruddy married his wife Laura on 2 June 2012. Prior to the Euro 2012 tournament, he jokingly cited breaking his finger as the reason he was able to have his wedding on that date.<ref name=fa/> He is nicknamed "The Iceman".<ref name=ice>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18092160 |title=John Ruddy's rise to the England Euro 2012 squad |first=Chris |last=Osborne |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=17 May 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
