{{For|the English goalkeeper|John Ruddy}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Jack Ruddy |fullname = John Robert Ruddy |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|12|27|df=y}} |height = 195 cm |birth_place = [[Glasgow]], Scotland |position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] |currentclub = [[UD San Sebastián de los Reyes|S.S. Reyes]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) |clubnumber = |youthclubs1 = [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] |youthclubs2 = [[Real Murcia]] |youthyears1 = 2004–2009 |youthyears2 = {{0|000}}?–2013 |years1 = 2013–2014 |clubs1 = [[Real Murcia]] |caps1 = 0 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2014–2016 |clubs2 = [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] |caps2 = 1 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2016– |clubs3 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps3 = 0 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2017–2018 |clubs4 = → [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] (loan) |caps4 = 5 |goals4 = 0 |years5 = 2018 |clubs5 = → [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]] (loan) |caps5 = 11 |goals5 = 0 |years6 = 2018–2019 |clubs6 = → [[FC Jumilla]] (loan) |caps6 = 4 |goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2019– |clubs7 = → [[UD San Sebastián de los Reyes|S.S. Reyes]] (loan) |caps7 = 0 |goals7 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2017 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 |club-update = 1 February 2018 |ntupdate = 4 March 2019 }} '''John Robert Ruddy''' (born 27 December 1997) is a Scottish [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Segunda División B]] club [[UD San Sebastián de los Reyes|S.S. Reyes]] on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Glasgow]], Ruddy was on the books of hometown team [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] from the age of seven to twelve, being coached by [[Andy Goram]], before emigrating to [[Murcia]] in Spain in 2010. At the age of fifteen, after impressing for Torre Pacheco, he signed a contract for [[Real Murcia]].{{cite news|last1=Parks|first1=Gordon|title=Ex-Rangers youth keeper signs dream deal with Spanish club Real Murcia|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/local-sport/ex-rangers-youth-keeper-signs-dream-2250819|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Daily Record|date=4 September 2013}} Ruddy went on trial with [[Villarreal CF|Villarreal]], but he was unable to sign a professional contract with any Spanish club due to a regulation requiring young players to have resided in Spain for at least five years.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/15185404.How_Barcelona_cost_Scotland_Under_21_goalkeeper_Jack_Ruddy_his_chance_at_making_it_big_in_La_Liga/ |title=How Barcelona cost Scotland Under-21 goalkeeper Jack Ruddy his chance at making it big in La Liga |first=Alan |last=Temple |work=The Herald |publisher=Herald & Times Group |date=27 March 2017 |accessdate=27 March 2017}} ===Bury=== On 30 July 2014, Ruddy returned to the United Kingdom, signing for [[Bury F.C.|Bury]].{{cite news|last1=Nelson|first1=Craig|title=Former Rangers youth keeper Jack Ruddy signs for Bury|url=http://www.theboltonnews.co.uk/sport/football/shakers/11375695.Former_Rangers_youth_keeper_Jack_Ruddy_signs_for_Bury/?ref=rss|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=The Bolton News|date=30 July 2014}} He was first featured in a matchday squad on 8 November, remaining an unused substitute for their 3–1 win over [[Hemel Hempstead Town]] at [[Gigg Lane]] in the first round of the [[FA Cup]].{{cite news|title=Bury 3-1 Hemel Hempstead|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29907066|accessdate=23 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 November 2014}} Ruddy was first included in a league game on 28 December, again remaining on the bench in a 2–0 [[Football League Two|League Two]] triumph of the same score against [[Mansfield Town]], repeating the feat four times as the team [[2014–15 Football League Two|earned promotion]] to [[Football League One|League One]].{{cite news|title=Bury 2-0 Mansfield|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30566652|accessdate=23 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 December 2014}} Ruddy made his professional debut on 14 November 2015, playing the full 90 minutes of a 3–1 League One loss at [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]]{{cite news|title=Gillingham 3-1 Bury|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34753746|accessdate=23 November 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 November 2015}} in what turned out to be his only first team appearance for Bury. ===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 29 August 2016 Ruddy signed for [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a two-year deal, with the option of a further year, for an undisclosed fee.{{cite news|title=Young keeper arrives|url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/news-young-keeper-arrives-3277270.aspx|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |date=29 August 2016 |accessdate=27 March 2017}} He was named on the bench once over the season, for a 3–1 loss at Derby County on 29 April 2017.{{cite news |title=Derby COunty 3–1 Wolverhampton Wanderers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39675692 |accessdate=7 February 2019 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 April 2017}} In December 2017, he extended his contract until the end of the 2019–20 campaign.{{cite news |title=Jack Ruddy: Wolverhampton Wanderers keeper signs new contract |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42427693 |accessdate=7 February 2019 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 December 2017}} On 31 August 2017, Ruddy was sent on loan to League One side [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] until 1 January. He was then loaned to [[Scottish League One]] club [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ayrunitedfc.co.uk/united-net-keeper-ruddy/ |title=United net keeper Ruddy |work= |publisher=Ayr United F.C. |date=12 January 2018 |accessdate=12 January 2018}} Ruddy was one of nine Wolves youngsters loaned to Spanish [[Segunda División B]] team [[FC Jumilla]] in August 2018.{{cite news |title=Wolves send nine player on loan to FC Jumilla |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/academy/20180831-wolves-send-nine-player-on-loan-to-fc-jumilla/ |accessdate=7 February 2019 |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |date=31 August 2018}} He made four appearances and was sent off at the end of his last game, a 2–2 draw at [[CD El Ejido]], for insulting the referee.{{cite news |title=El FC Jumilla remonta en El Ejido con un Donovan Wilson estelar (2-2) |url=http://sietediasjumilla.es/el-fc-jumilla-remonta-en-el-ejido-con-un-donovan-wilson-estelar-2-2/|trans-title=FC Jumilla come back in El Ejido with a stellar Donovan Wilson (2-2) |accessdate=7 February 2019 |publisher=Siete Días Jumilla |date=17 December 2018 |language=Spanish}} On 1 February 2019, he joined [[UD San Sebastián de los Reyes|S.S. Reyes]] of the same league until the end of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2019/01/31/wolves-trio-secure-overseas-loan-moves/ |title=Wolves trio secure overseas loan moves|work=Shropshire Star|date=1 February 2019 |accessdate=1 February 2019}} ==International career== Ruddy has represented Scotland at the [[Scotland national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[Scotland national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Scotland national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels.[http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/football_player_profile.cfm?page=1848&playerID=141929&squadID=5 Jack Ruddy] ==Career statistics== {{Updated|match played 10 September 2018}} {|class="wikitable" {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Sylvain Deslandes | fullname = Sylvain Boris Nabil Deslandes{{cite web|title=Retained List 2015-16|url=http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf|publisher=English Football League|format=PDF|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202052144/http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf|archivedate=2 December 2016}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|4|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kouoptamo]], Cameroon | height = 1.86m | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[FC Jumilla]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = 2007–2008 | youthclubs1 = AM. S. Soliers | youthyears2 = 2008–2010 | youthclubs2 = [[USON Mondeville]] | youthyears3 = 2010–2015 | youthclubs3 = [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]] | years1 = 2013–2015 | clubs1 = [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen II]] | caps1 = 8 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2015– | clubs2 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps2 = 4 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017 | clubs3 = → [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] (loan) | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] (loan) | caps4 = 2 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = → [[FC Jumilla]] (Loan) | caps5 = 4 | goals5 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[France national under-16 football team|France U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2013–2014 | nationalteam2 = [[France national under-17 football team|France U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2014 | nationalteam3 = [[France national under-18 football team|France U18]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2016 | nationalteam4 = [[France national under-19 football team|France U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 3 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2016– | nationalteam5 = [[France national under-20 football team|France U20]] | nationalcaps5 = 1 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | club-update = 24 September 2018 | nationalteam-update = 08:50, 8 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Sylvain Boris Nabil Deslandes''' (born 25 April 1997) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Segunda División B]] club [[FC Jumilla]] on loan from English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. He has represented France at under-16 through under-20 level. ==Career== Deslandes moved upon the expiry of his contract with French club [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]] to join English side [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in July 2015, agreeing a two-year deal (with the option of a third year).{{cite news| title=Deslandes set to sign| publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C| url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/deslandes-set-to-sign-2487827.aspx| date=10 June 2015| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906133926/http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/deslandes-set-to-sign-2487827.aspx| archivedate=6 September 2015| df=dmy-all}} He made his club debut on 25 August 2015 in a League Cup win over [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]].{{cite news| title=Wolves 2–1 Barnet|publisher=BBC Sport| url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33969991| date=25 August 2015}} On 31 January 2017, he joined [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.buryfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/confirmed-left-back-deslandes-arrives-from-wolves-3548768.aspx|title=Confirmed: Left Back Deslandes arrives from Wolves|publisher=Bury F.C.|date=31 January 2017}} He returned to Wolves at the end of the 2016–17 season having made no appearances for Bury. He appeared regularly under [[Nuno Espírito Santo]] in 2017–18 pre-season and played 90 minutes in the 2–0 [[EFL Cup|Carabao Cup]] win against [[Premier League]] side [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/09/19/wolves-defender-deslandes-loving-being-in-land-of-sylvain/}} He also came on during Wolves' 2–1 [[EFL Championship|Championship]] victory against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on September 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/09/19/wolves-defender-deslandes-loving-being-in-land-of-sylvain/}} On 3 January 2018, he agreed to join [[Portsmouth F.C.]] as a [[left-back]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180102-ronan-and-deslandes-leave-on-loan/|title=Ronan And Deslandes Leave On Loan|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|date=3 January 2018}} He returned to Wolves at the end of the season having made only two appearances for Portsmouth, after manager [[Kenny Jackett]] had said his future was not at [[left-back]] but [[centre-back]] as Deslandes was a player with "power" and "athleticism".{{cite web|url=https://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/football/pompey/pompey-boss-deslandes-future-not-at-left-back-1-8491835}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{Updated|match played 9 September 2018}} {| {{Infobox football biography | name = Connor Johnson | fullname = Connor William Johnson{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-released-and-retained-list---2016-17.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 20th May 2017 |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=41 |accessdate=7 September 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1998|3|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kettering]], England{{cite web |title=C. Johnson |url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/connor-johnson/452929/ |publisher=Soccerway |accessdate=7 September 2018}} | height = | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre back]] | currentclub = [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = 20 | youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] | youthyears2 = |youthclubs2 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | years1 = 2016– |clubs1 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps1 = 0 |goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2017 |clubs2 = → [[Boreham Wood F.C.|Boreham Wood]] (loan) |caps2 = 0 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2017–2018 |clubs3 = → [[A.F.C. Telford United|AFC Telford United]] (loan) |caps3 = 27 |goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2018– |clubs4 = → [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] (loan) |caps4 = 3 |goals4 = 0 | club-update = 12:04, 23 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Connor William Johnson''' (born 10 March 1998) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[EFL League One]] club [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]]. ==Club career== Johnson started his youth career with the academy of [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] and later joined the academy of [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton]]. While progressing through the youth ranks, he went on to captain the under-23 team. He signed his first professional contract with the club at the beginning of the 2016–17 season.{{cite web |title=Meet The Under 23s |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/under-23/20170505-meet-the-under-23s/ |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=5 May 2017}} On 27 March 2017, Johnson was loaned out to [[Boreham Wood F.C.|Boreham Wood]].{{cite web |title=Wood welcome defensive cover |url=https://www.borehamwoodfootballclub.co.uk/uncategorized/wood-welcome-defensive-cover/ |publisher=Boreham Wood F.C. |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=27 March 2017}} On 5 September 2017, he was loaned out to [[A.F.C. Telford United|AFC Telford United]] for one month.{{cite web |author1=Nathan Judah |title=Telford sign Wolves' Connor Johnson on one-month loan deal |url=https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/football/afc-telford-united/2017/09/05/telford-sign-wolves-connor-johnson-on-one-month-loan-deal/ |publisher=Shropstire Star |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=5 September 2017}} However, ten days later, he was handed a two-match suspension by [[The Football Association|the FA]] for playing a [[EFL Trophy]] match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in January 2017 despite being ineligible for doing so.{{cite web |title=Suspension For Defender |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/under-23/20170915-suspension-for-defender/ |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=15 September 2017}} In February 2018, he extended his loan till the end of the season.{{cite web |author1=Lewis Cox |title=AFC Telford assistant Sean Parrish praises loanee defender Connor Johnson |url=https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/football/afc-telford-united/2018/02/01/afc-telford-assistant-sean-parrish-praises-loanee-defender-connor-johnson/ |publisher=Shropshire United |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=1 February 2018}} On 31 August 2018, Johnson was loaned out to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] for the entire season.{{cite web |title=Connor Johnson and Connor Ronan: Wolves duo join Walsall on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45375788 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=31 August 2018}} Four days later, he made his debut, starting in a 2–1 victory over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] in the [[EFL Trophy]].{{cite web |author1=Joseph Masi |title=Checkatrade Trophy: Burton Albion 1 Walsall 2 - Report and pictures |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/walsall-fc/2018/09/04/checkatrade-trophy-burton-albion-1-walsall-2---report-and-pictures/ |publisher=Express and Star |accessdate=7 September 2018 |date=4 September 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{Updated|23 January 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup|League Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=3|[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |[[2016–17 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2016–17]] |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |0||0||0||0||0||0||colspan=2|—||0||0 |- |[[2017–18 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2017–18]] |Championship |0||0||0||0||0||0||colspan=2|—||0||0 |- !colspan=2|Total !0||0||0||0||0||0||colspan=2|—||0||0 |- |rowspan=1|[[Boreham Wood F.C.|Boreham Wood]] (loan) |[[2016–17 National League|2016–17]]{{soccerbase season|94680|2016|accessdate=7 September 2018}} |[[National League (division)|National League]] |0||0||colspan=2|—||0||0||0||0||0||0 |- |rowspan=1|[[A.F.C. Telford United|AFC Telford United]] (loan) |[[2017–18 National League|2017–18]] |[[National League North]] |27||1||2||0||0||0||1{{efn|Appearance in [[FA Trophy]]|name=FAT}}||0||30||1 |- |rowspan=1|[[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] (loan) |[[2018–19 EFL League One|2018–19]] |[[EFL League One|League One]] |3||0||1||0||0||0||3{{efn|Appearances in [[EFL Trophy]]|name=EFT}}||0||7||0 |- !colspan=3|Career total !30||1||3||0||0||0||4||0||37||1 |} {{notelist}} ==Style of play== Johnson plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]]. [[Sean Parrish]] (assistant manager of AFC Telford United) said that Johnson has "got a good attitude and he wants to learn, improve and play at a high level". ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Soccerbase|94680}} *{{Soccerway|connor-johnson/452929}} {{Walsall F.C. squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, Connor}} [[Category:1998 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Association football defenders]] [[Category:People from Kettering]] [[Category:Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. players]] [[Category:Boreham Wood F.C. players]] [[Category:A.F.C. Telford United players]] [[Category:Walsall F.C. players]] [[Category:English Football League players]] [[Category:National League (English football) players]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Portuguese name|Gonçalves|Miranda}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Roderick |image = |fullname = Roderick Jefferson Gonçalves Miranda |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|3|30|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Odivelas]], Portugal |height = {{height|m=1.92}} |position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre back]] |currentclub = [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) |clubnumber = 25 |youthyears1 = 1999–2000 | youthclubs1 = [[Odivelas F.C.|Odivelas]] |youthyears2 = 2000–2010 | youthclubs2 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] |years1 = 2010–2013 | clubs1 = [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] | caps1 = 7 | goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2011–2012 | clubs2 = → [[Servette FC|Servette]] (loan) | caps2 = 24 | goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2012 | clubs3 = → [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]] (loan) | caps3 = 3 | goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2012–2013 | clubs4 = [[S.L. Benfica B|Benfica B]] | caps4 = 5 | goals4 = 0 |years5 = 2013–2017 | clubs5 = [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave]] | caps5 = 72 | goals5 = 4 |years6 = 2017– | clubs6 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps6 = 17 | goals6 = 0 |years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = → [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] (loan) | caps7 = 8 | goals7 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2007 | nationalteam1 = [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2008 | nationalteam2 = [[Portugal national under-18 football team|Portugal U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 3 | nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 2008–2010 | nationalteam3 = [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 0 |nationalyears4 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam4 = [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 14 | nationalgoals4 = 0 |club-update = 21:55, 10 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = }} '''Roderick Jefferson Gonçalves Miranda''' (born 30 March 1991), known simply as '''Roderick''', is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]] for Greek club [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. ==Club career== ===Benfica=== Born in [[Odivelas]], Roderick arrived in [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]]'s youth academy in 2000 (aged nine), from [[Lisbon]] neighbours [[Odivelas F.C.|Odivelas]]. He was promoted to the first team nine years later after having played in all the youth ranks of the [[Primeira Liga]] giants, and appeared in some pre-season and [[Taça da Liga]] matches in [[2009–10 Primeira Liga|his debut campaign]]. For [[2011–12 Swiss Super League|2011–12]], Roderick was loaned to [[Servette FC|Servette]] in [[Switzerland]] – coached by former Benfica player [[João Resende Alves|João Alves]] – in a [[2011–12 Swiss Super League|season]]-long move.{{cite web|url=http://www.sabado.pt/ultima-hora/detalhe/Roderick--%C2%ABO-inicio-de-uma-grande-carreira%C2%BB|title=Roderick: "O início de uma grande carreira"|trans-title=Roderick: «The start of a great career»|publisher=[[Sábado (magazine)|Sábado]]|language=pt|date=12 November 2011|accessdate=16 April 2018}} On 31 July 2012 he joined [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] in [[La Liga]], in the same situation; he returned to the [[Estádio da Luz]] in the following [[transfer window]], however.{{cite news|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/deportivo/2012/12/28/roderick-deja-deportivo/00031356713455346285110.htm|title=Roderick deja el Deportivo|trans-title=Roderick leaves Deportivo|newspaper=[[La Voz de Galicia]]|language=es|date=28 December 2012|accessdate=13 February 2014}} ===Rio Ave=== Roderick was released by Benfica in August 2013, signing a five-year deal with [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rioave-fc.pt/noticias/verdetalhes.php?registo=2999|title=Roderick assinou por 5 épocas|trans-title=Roderick signed for 5 seasons|publisher=Rio Ave F.C|language=pt|date=3 August 2013|accessdate=3 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807011011/http://www.rioave-fc.pt/noticias/verdetalhes.php?registo=2999|archivedate=7 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} He scored three goals in 33 games in [[2016–17 Primeira Liga|his fourth season]],{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/futebol/1a-liga/noticias/interior/moreirense-rio-ave-empate-com-final-de-loucos-5458848.html|title=Moreirense-Rio Ave: empate com final de loucos|trans-title=Moreirense-Rio Ave: draw with crazy ending|newspaper=[[O Jogo]]|language=pt|date=23 October 2016|accessdate=14 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cdnacional.pt/nacional-derrotado-vila-do-conde/|title=Nacional derrotado em Vila do Conde|trans-title=Nacional defeated in Vila do Conde|publisher=C.D. Nacional|language=pt|date=18 December 2016|accessdate=16 April 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/desporto/ao-minuto-fc-porto-rio-ave_e977537|title=FC Porto 4–2 Rio Ave|publisher=[[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal]]|language=pt|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=14 June 2017}} helping to a seventh-place finish. ===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 13 June 2017, Roderick joined [[EFL Championship|English Championship]] team [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a four-year contract for an undisclosed fee.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40268288|title=Roderick Miranda: Wolves sign Rio Ave defender on four-year deal|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 June 2017|accessdate=12 July 2018}} He made his debut on 5 August, playing the whole of a 1–0 home win against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40760787|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 1–0 Middlesbrough|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 August 2017|accessdate=12 July 2018}} Roderick continued in the league team for 14 matches, before falling out of favour with manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2018/04/04/do-has-nuno-indicated-that-danny-batth-wont-be-at-wolves-next-se/|title=Has Nuno indicated that Danny Batth will not be at Wolves next season?|publisher=HITC|first=Danny|last=Owen|date=4 April 2018|accessdate=16 July 2018}} He finished [[2017–18 EFL Championship|the season]] with 19 appearances in all competitions,{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/transfer/news/11699/11434633/prince-oniangue-leaves-for-caen-wolves-loan-out-roderick-miranda|title=Prince Oniangue leaves for Caen, Wolves loan out Roderick Miranda|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|first=Matthew|last=Treadwell|date=12 July 2018|accessdate=16 July 2018}} as Wolves were promoted as champions.{{cite news|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2018/07/11/roderick-miranda-thanks-wolves-after-sealing-loan-exit/|title=Roderick Miranda thanks Wolves after sealing loan exit|newspaper=[[Express & Star]]|first=Tim|last=Spiers|location=Wolverhampton|date=11 July 2018|accessdate=12 July 2018}} ===Olympiacos=== On 11 July 2018, Roderick joined [[Greek Superleague]] club [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180711-miranda-joins-olympiacos/|title=Miranda joins Olympiacos|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C|date=11 July 2018|accessdate=12 July 2018}} ==International career== Of [[Brazilians|Brazilian descent]],{{cite news|url=http://www.record.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/rio-ave/detalhe/pai-de-roderick-diz-que-o-filho-esta-tranquilo.html|title=Pai de Roderick diz que o filho "está tranquilo"|trans-title=Roderick's father says son "is calm"|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=pt|date=29 December 2017|accessdate=16 April 2018}} Roderick chose to represent [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] internationally and went on to win 45 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] all youth categories comprised. He represented the [[Portugal national under-20 football team|under-20 team]] at the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2011 FIFA World Cup]] in Colombia, often partnering [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]]'s [[Nuno Reis]] in an eventual runner-up finish.{{cite news|url=https://www.publico.pt/2011/08/22/desporto/noticia/mundial-vai-mudar-pouco-na-vida-imediata-dos-sub20-portugueses-1508644|title=Mundial vai mudar pouco na vida imediata dos sub-20 portugueses|trans-title=World Cup will change little in short-term life of Portugal's under-20|newspaper=[[Público (Portugal)|Público]]|language=pt|date=22 August 2011|accessdate=16 April 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 4 October 2018}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|National Cup !colspan=2|[[League Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=5|[[S.L. {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox football biography | name=Jordan Graham | image= | fullname=Jordan Graham{{Cite news|title=Premier League Clubs submit Squad Lists |url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |publisher=Premier League |format=PDF |page=35 |date=4 February 2014 |accessdate=12 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316063138/http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Premier-League-Squad-Lists-January-2014.pdf |archivedate=16 March 2014 |df= }} | birth_date={{birth date and age|1995|3|5|df=y}} | birth_place=[[Coventry]], England | height= | position=[[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = 18 | youthyears1 = 2002–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Aston Villa Under-21s and Academy|Aston Villa]] | years1 = 2013–2015 | clubs1 = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2013 | clubs2 = → [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 2 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2014 | clubs3 = → [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] (loan) | caps3 = 1 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2014–2015 | clubs4 = → [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] (loan) | caps4 = 0 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2015– | clubs5 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps5 = 14 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2015 | clubs6 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | caps6 = 5 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2017–2018 | clubs7 = → [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (loan) | caps7 = 3 | goals7 = 0 | years8 = 2018–2019 | clubs8 = → [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] (loan) | caps8 = 4 | goals8 = 0 | years9 = 2019– | clubs9 = → [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] (loan) | caps9 = 8 | goals9 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = Republic of Ireland U15 | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps2 = 5 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2011–2012 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps3 = 11 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 15:06, 23 February 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = }} '''Jordan Graham''' (born 5 March 1995) is an English professional footballer who plays as a winger for [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] . Graham has represented both [[England national football team|England]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] at youth level. He is a product of the [[Aston Villa Under-21s and Academy|Aston Villa Academy]], having spent twelve years there as a junior. ==Career== Graham is a product of the Aston Villa youth academy and was a member of their [[NextGen Series]] winning side in the 2012–13 season. He signed a professional contract with Villa in March 2012.{{cite web | url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10265~2634177,00.html| title=Academy starlet Graham signs professional contract| publisher=Aston Villa F.C|date= 7 March 2012}} In November, he joined [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on loan, where he made his professional debut on 7 December 2013 in a 2–1 win over [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]].{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25163687 | title = Ipswich 2–1 Huddersfield | publisher = BBC Sport| date = 7 December 2013}} Graham also made an appearance in the victory over [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] before he returned to Villa at the end of December 2013.{{cite web | url = http://www.twtd.co.uk/ipswich-town-news/24305? | title= Loanee Returns to Villa | publisher=Ipswich Town F.C | date = 31 December 2013}} On 10 January 2014, he joined League One side [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] on a one-month loan deal,{{Cite web |title=Graham comes to city |url=http://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/news/article/graham-joins-city-1285252.aspx |publisher=Bradford City AFC |date=10 January 2014}} for whom he made one appearance: against his future club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 1 February 2014.{{Cite web | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25891950| title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–0 Bradford City| publisher=BBC Sport| date=1 February 2014}} The winger joined Wolverhampton Wanderers, now returned to the Championship, in November 2014 on loan until the January transfer window.{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30238820| title =Aston Villa: Wolves sign midfielder Jordan Graham on loan| publisher = BBC Sport| date =27 November 2014}} Injury prevented him from making any appearances during this loan period,{{cite web | url =http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/jordan-graham-completes-move-2182698.aspx| title=Jordan Graham completes move| publisher = Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C | date = 5 January 2015}} but he signed a permanent 18-month deal with the club on 5 January 2015 for an undisclosed fee.{{cite web | url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30682931| title=Jordan Graham completes move| publisher =BBC Sport| date = 5 January 2015}} After failing to make a first-team appearance for Wolves, he was sent on a month-long loan to League Two side [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in September 2015.{{cite news| title=Oxford United: Winger Jordan Graham set to join on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34381097|date=28 September 2015}} Following a successful initial month, his loan was extended by two months,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34621656 |title=Jordan Graham: Winger extends Oxford loan by two months |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 October 2015|accessdate=27 October 2015}} but a few days later he was recalled by Wolves after an injury crisis at his parent club.{{cite web |url=http://www.oufc.co.uk/news/article/oxford-united-wolves-jordan-graham-2767506.aspx |title=Winger Graham Returns To Wolves |publisher=Oxford United F.C. |date=27 October 2015 |accessdate=27 October 2015}} Graham scored his first goal in his club career for Wolverhampton Wanderers on 28 December 2015 in the 52nd minute of a Championship game against [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] at The Valley.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35147801 |title=Charlton Athletic 0 Wolverhampton Wanderers 2 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2015 |accessdate=1 February 2016}} He suffered torn knee ligaments during a game against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 16 January 2016. Despite this, Graham extended his contract with Wolves until the end of the 2017–18 season, with the club having the option of two additional years.{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35533293| publisher=BBC Sport| title=Wolves: Jordan Graham and Kortney Hause extend contracts|date=9 February 2016}} The initial prognosis of his injury was that he was expected to be missing from action for between nine and 12 months,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35343431 |title=Jordan Graham: Wolves winger out for nine months with injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 January 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016}} but after suffering several setbacks during his recovery, he did not return to first-team football until 15 months later, on 25 April 2017, in a 1–0 defeat against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]] at Molineux.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39035260| publisher=BBC Sport| title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 0–1 Huddersfield Town|date=25 April 2017}} On 31 August 2017, he joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] rivals [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20170831-graham-loaned-to-fulham/|title=Graham Loaned To Fulham |publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|date=31 August 2017}} On 15 January 2018, after making just three league appearances, Graham returned to Wolves.{{cite web|url=http://www.fulhamfc.com/news/2018/january/15/jordan-graham-returns-to-wolves|title=Graham Returns To Wolves|publisher=Fulham F.C.|date=15 January 2018|accessdate= 27 March 2018}} On 28 August 2018, Graham signed for [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web|url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/sport/town-sign-wolves-winger-graham-1-5670222|title=Ipswich Town sign Wolves winger Jordan Graham|publisher=EADT|date=28 August 2018|accessdate= 28 August 2018}} After [[Paul Lambert]] replaced Paul Hurst as Ipswich manager, Graham began training with Oxford United, with a view to an official loan in January,[https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2018/11/15/jordan-graham-snubbed-by-ex-wolves-boss-paul-lambert-at-ipswich/ "Jordan Graham snubbed by ex-Wolves boss Paul Lambert at Ipswich"] Shropshire Star November 15 2018 which was confirmed in December 2018.{{cite news |url=https://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/oxfordunited/usnews/17319558.jordan-graham-to-return-on-loan-at-oxford-united-next-week/ |first=David |last=Pritchard |title=Jordan Graham to return on loan at Oxford United next week |newspaper=Oxford Mail |date=25 December 2018 |accessdate=4 January 2019}} He scored his first Oxford goal, and the second League goal of his career, with a well-taken free kick in a surprise away victory over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 23 February 2019.{{cite news |url=https://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/oxfordunited/usnews/17456186.oxford-united-hero-jordan-graham-on-a-high/ |first=Jack |last=Johnson |title=Oxford United hero Jordan Graham on a high |newspaper=Oxford Mail |date=25 February 2019 |accessdate=25 February 2019}} ==International career== Graham has played for the [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] side, being part of the squad that retained the 2010–11 [[Victory Shield]].{{cite web | url=http://www.thefa.com/england/All-Teams/Players/g/JordanGraham | title=Jordan Graham | publisher=www.thefa.com | accessdate=8 December 2013}} He has also represented the [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] side, playing in and winning the 2012 Algarve Tournament.{{cite web | url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/ReservesProfile/0,,10265~2388257,00.html | title=Jordan Graham Squad Profile | publisher=www.avfc.co.uk | accessdate=8 December 2013}} Graham also represented the [[Republic of Ireland national football team]] at under-15 level in the 2010 Tri-Nations tournament, scoring twice against Northern Ireland U15s.{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/international/youth-teams/under-15/100982-republic-u15s-complete-double-over-north.html |title=Republic U15s Complete Double over North |publisher=Football Association of Ireland |accessdate=8 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213001950/http://www.fai.ie/international/youth-teams/under-15/100982-republic-u15s-complete-double-over-north.html |archivedate=13 December 2013 |df= }} {{Infobox football biography |name = Connor Ronan |image = |image_size = |caption = |fullname = Connor Patrick Ronan{{cite web|title=Retained List 2016-17|url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-released-and-retained-list---2016-17.pdf|publisher=English Football League|format=PDF|accessdate=13 June 2017}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1998|3|6|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Rochdale]], England |height = 1.78 m{{cite web |title=Connor Ronan |publisher=Walsall F.C. |accessdate=7 December 2018 |url= https://www.saddlers.co.uk/teams/first-team/midfielder/connor-ronan/}} |position = [[Midfielder]] |currentclub = [[FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|Dunajská Streda]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) |clubnumber = 27 |youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2009 |youthclubs1 = Copperpot J.F.C. |youthyears2 = 2009–2014 |youthclubs2 = [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] |youthyears3 = 2014–2016 |youthclubs3 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |years1 = 2016– |clubs1 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps1 = 7 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2018 |clubs2 = → [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] (loan) |caps2 = 16 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2018–2019 |clubs3 = → [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] (loan) |caps3 = 11 |goals3 = 0 |years4 = 2019 |clubs4 = → [[FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|Dunajská Streda]] (loan) |caps4 = 4 |goals4 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2015 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2015 |nationalteam2 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-17 football team|Republic of Ireland U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 5 |nationalgoals2 = 1 |nationalyears3 = 2015–2017 |nationalteam3 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-19 football team|Republic of Ireland U19]] |nationalcaps3 = 8 |nationalgoals3 = 1 |nationalyears4 = 2017– |nationalteam4 = [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland U21]] |nationalcaps4 = 2 |nationalgoals4 = 0 |club-update =11:21, 13 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Connor Patrick Ronan''' (born 6 March 1998) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|Dunajská Streda]], on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. He was born in England, but represents Republic of Ireland at international youth level. ==Career== Ronan started his career by Copperpot J.F.C.[https://www.rochdaleonline.co.uk/sites/copperpot-jfc/under-11s-win-bowlee-tournament The semi was a more open game and Copperpot stormed to a 2 goal lead through Connor Ronan and Sam Astin to progress.] and attended [[St Cuthbert's RC High School]] in [[Rochdale]] with whom he reached the final of the English National Schools Cup as a year 7 in 2009 with a team that also included [[Axel Tuanzebe]], Kisimba Kisimba and [[Johny Diba]], who all went on to become pros.http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/manchester-united-youngster-axel-tuanzebe-10396435 He then joined [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], his boyhood club in which he stayed there until he joined [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at the age of 16.{{cite news|title=Five Things We Have Learned About Connor Ronan|url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/five-things-we-have-learned-about-connor-ronan-2279740.aspx|work=[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.]]|publisher=EFL Digital Limited|date=2 February 2015|accessdate=17 December 2016}} Ronan made three appearances for the team's [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. Development Squad and Academy|development squad]] in the [[2016–17 EFL Trophy]], scoring a goal in their 4–0 win over [[EFL League Two]] team [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]].{{cite news|title=Youngsters Make Progress In Cup|url=http://www.wolves.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/report-youngsters-make-progress-in-cup-3406677.aspx|work=[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.]]|publisher=EFL Digital Limited|date=8 November 2016|accessdate=17 December 2016}} With [[Paul Lambert]] as manager, Ronan was part of the first-team squad for the first time on 26 November 2016,{{cite news|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2016/11/26/wolves-vs-sheffield-wednesday-live/|title=Wolves 0 Sheffield Wednesday 2 - As it happened|date=26 November 2016|accessdate=17 December 2016|work=[[Express & Star]]|publisher=[[MNA Media]]}} as an unused substitute in the 2–0 defeat to [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]. Ronan made his debut on 17 December 2016, replacing [[Hélder Costa (footballer)|Hélder Costa]] for the final nine minutes of the team's 2–0 win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38271717|title=Nottingham Forest 0-2 Wolverhampton Wanderers|date=17 December 2016|accessdate=17 December 2016|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2016/12/17/nottingham-forest-0-wolves-2-report/soccer-sky-bet-championship-nottingham-forest-v-wolverhampton-wanderers-41/|title=Nottingham Forest 0 Wolves 2 - Report and pictures|date=17 December 2016|accessdate=17 December 2016|work=[[Express & Star]]|publisher=[[MNA Media]]|quote=Lambert did too. He sent on youngster Connor Ronan for his professional debut in place of Costa.}} On 31 August 2018, Ronan joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on loan until January 2019 along with team-mate Connor Johnson.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45375788 |title=Connor Johnson and Connor Ronan: Wolves duo join Walsall on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 August 2018 |accessdate=1 September 2018 }} Ronan returned to Wolves at the conclusion of his loan spell, making 15 appearances in all competitions for Walsall.{{cite web|url=https://www.saddlers.co.uk/news/2019/january/ronan-returns-to-wolves|title=Ronan Returns to Wolves|publisher=Walsall F.C.|date=2 January 2019}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 1 January 2019}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !colspan="3"|League !colspan="2"|[[FA Cup]] !colspan="2"|[[EFL Cup|League Cup]] !colspan="2"|Other !colspan="2"|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan="4"|[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |[[2016–17 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2016–17]]{{soccerbase season|87731|2016|accessdate=2 September 2017}} |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |4||0||2||0||0||0||3Appearances in the [[EFL Trophy]] with [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. Development Squad and Academy|Wolverhampton Wanderers U23s]]||1||9||1 |- |[[2017–18 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|87731|2017|accessdate=2 September 2017}} |Championship |3||0||0||0||4||0||colspan="2|—||7||0 |- |[[2018–19 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2018–19]]{{soccerbase season|87731|2018|accessdate=6 October 2018}} |[[Premier League]] |0||0||0||0||0||0||colspan="2|—||0||0 |- !colspan="2"|Total !7!!0!!2!!0!!4!!0!!3!!1!!16!!1 |- |[[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] (loan) |[[2017–18 Portsmouth F.C. season|2017–18]] |[[EFL League One|League One]] |16||0||0||0||0||0||1Appearance in the [[EFL Trophy]]||0||17||0 |- |[[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] (loan) |[[2018–19 Walsall F.C. season|2018–19]] |League One |11||0||0||0||0||0||4||0||15||0 |- !colspan="3"|Career total !34!!0!!2!!0!!4!!0!!8!!1!!48!!1 |} {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Soccerbase}} *{{Soccerway}} {{FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ronan, Connor}} [[Category:1998 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Rochdale]] [[Category:English footballers]] [[Category:Republic of Ireland association footballers]] [[Category:Association football midfielders]] [[Category:English people of Irish descent]] [[Category:England youth international footballers]] [[Category:Republic of Ireland youth international footballers]] [[Category:Rochdale A.F.C. players]] [[Category:Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. players]] [[Category:Portsmouth F.C. players]] [[Category:Walsall F.C. players]] [[Category:FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda players]] [[Category:English Football League players]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in Slovakia]]

(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) |clubnumber = |youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[S.B.V. Excelsior|Excelsior]] |youthyears2 = |youthclubs2 = [[NAC Breda]] |youthyears3 = 2009–2016 |youthclubs3 = [[Feyenoord]] |youthyears4 = 2016–2017 |youthclubs4 = [[Nike Academy]] |youthyears5 = 2017–2018 |youthclubs5 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |years1 = 2018– |clubs1 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |caps1 = 0 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2018–2019 |clubs2 = → [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] (loan) |caps2 = 6 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2019– |clubs3 = → [[FC Jumilla]] (loan) |caps3 = 0 |goals3 = 0 |club-update = 14:54, 22 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Sherwin Dandery Seedorf''' (born 17 March 1998) is a Dutch professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for Spanish club [[FC Jumilla]], on loan from English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]]. ==Early and personal life== Seedorf was born in Suriname. He is distantly related to [[Clarence Seedorf]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/sport/16398227.bantams-winger-seedorf-used-to-family-comparison/|title=Bantams flyer Seedorf can handle name fame|date=4 August 2018|accessdate=6 August 2018|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}} ==Career== After beginning his career with [[S.B.V. Excelsior|Excelsior]] and [[NAC Breda]], Seedorf spent seven years with [[Feyenoord]], and later played for [[Nike Academy]] before signing for [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in January 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/02/14/sherwin-seedorf-wolves-sign-dutch-winger-on-deal-after-impressing-on-trial/|title=Sherwin Seedorf: Wolves sign Dutch winger on deal after impressing on trial|date=14 February 2017|accessdate=22 June 2018|publisher=Express and Star}} He signed on loan for [[Bradford City A.F.C.|Bradford City]] in June 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bradfordcityfc.co.uk/news/2018/june/city-snap-up-seedorf/|title=CITY SNAP UP SEEDORF|date=22 June 2018|accessdate=22 June 2018|publisher=Bradford City A.F.C.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/news/16308691.bradford-city-dutch-winger-seedorf-signs-on-loan/|title=Bradford City: Dutch winger Seedorf signs on loan|date=22 June 2018|accessdate=22 June 2018|author=Simon Parker|publisher=Telegraph & Argus}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44582268|title=Sherwin Seedorf: Wolves winger joins Bradford City on loan|date=22 June 2018|accessdate=11 January 2019|publisher=BBC Sport}} He moved on loan to Spanish club [[FC Jumilla]] in January 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.mundodeportivo.com/futbol/20190120/454211071460/sherwin-seedorf-sobrino-del-exmadridista-clarence-seedorf-llega-al-jumilla.html|title=Sherwin Seedorf, sobrino del exmadridista {{Spanish name|Mir|Vicente}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Rafa Mir | image = | caption = | image_size = | fullname = Rafael Mir Vicente | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|6|18|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Murcia]], Spain | height = 1.91 m | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Javalí Nuevo | youthyears2 = 2006–2007 | youthclubs2 = [[ElPozo Murcia FS|ElPozo Murcia]] | youthyears3 = 2007–2009 | youthclubs3 = Ranero | youthyears4 = 2009–2011 | youthclubs4 = [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] | youthyears5 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs5 = [[Real Murcia|Murcia]] | youthyears6 = 2012–2016 | youthclubs6 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | years1 = 2015–2018 | clubs1 = [[Valencia CF Mestalla|Valencia B]] | caps1 = 60| goals1 = 25 | years2 = 2015–2018 | clubs2 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | caps2 = 2 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps3 = 2 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] (loan) | caps4 = 18 | goals4 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2018– | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 5 | medaltemplates = | club-update = 11 October 2018 | nationalteam-update = 21 March 2019 }} '''Rafael "Rafa" Mir Vicente''' (born 18 June 1997) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[UD Las Palmas]], on loan from English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. ==Club career== ===Youth career=== Born in [[Murcia]], Mir began his career playing [[futsal]] with CD Javalí Nuevo. After a 120-goal spell at [[ElPozo Murcia FS]] he began playing full football with Ranero CF, scoring 57 and 84 goals in his respective seasons before joining [[FC Barcelona]]. Mir's 32 goals at [[La Masia]] earned him a return to his [[Region of Murcia|native region]] and [[Real Murcia]], where a 45-goal haul led to the attention of [[Valencia CF]]. He made his senior debut for [[Valencia CF Mestalla|the reserves]] on 1 March 2015, as an 88th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Wilfried Zahibo]] in a 2–1 [[Segunda División B]] loss at [[CE L'Hospitalet]]. ===Valencia=== Mir scored his first senior goal on 7 March 2015, netting the last in a 2–0 win over [[CF Badalona]] at the [[Ciudad Deportiva de Paterna]].{{cite news|title=El Mestalla sufre pero se impone|trans-title=Mestalla suffer but impose themselves|url=http://www.levante-emv.com/deportes/2015/03/09/mestalla-sufre-impone/1236033.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=Levante EMV|date=9 March 2015|language=Spanish}} He finished [[2014–15 Segunda División B|the campaign]] with four appearances, as his side narrowly avoided relegation. The following season, Mir excelled in the [[UEFA Youth League]], scoring consecutive braces in victories over [[K.A.A. Gent]].{{cite news|title=Perfect Arsenal forge on in Youth League|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2295564.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=20 October 2015}}{{cite news|title=Holders Chelsea assured of top-two finish|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2301040.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=4 November 2015}} On 14 November 2015, he was given his first start for the B-side, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–4 loss at another [[reserve team]], [[Villarreal CF B]].{{cite news|title=El Valencia Mestalla naufraga ante el Villarreal B|trans-title=Valencia Mestalla sink against Villarreal B|url=http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2015/11/14/sigue--villarreal-b-/276272.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=Super Deporte|date=14 November 2015|language=Spanish}} On 24 November 2015, Mir was called up to the main squad by manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]] for a [[La Liga]] game against [[UD Las Palmas]];{{cite news|last1=Gimeno|first1=Manu|title=Nuno se lleva a Rafa Mir y recupera a pesos pesados|trans-title=Nuno brings in Rafa Mir and regains heavyweights|url=http://valencia.eldesmarque.com/valencia-cf/noticias/8576-convocatoria-valencia-las-palmas-nuno-se-lleva-a-rafa-mir|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=El Desmarque|date=20 November 2015|language=Spanish}} he was an unused substitute in the 1–1 draw at the [[Mestalla Stadium]].{{cite news|title=Viera gets the point for Las Palmas as Valencia are left frustrated|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/spanish-primera-division/match/433862/valencia-las-palmas/report|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=ESPN|date=21 November 2015}} He made his professional debut on 25 November, starting in a [[UEFA Champions League]] group stage match away to [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]],{{cite news|last1=Rocha Rodrigues|first1=Luís|last2=Sousa|first2=Vasco|title=Para sacudir a crise, Nuno estreia Rafa Mir, de 18 anos|trans-title=To end the crisis, Nuno chooses, Rafa Mir, 18|url=http://www.zerozero.pt/news.php?id=165227|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=ZeroZero|date=24 November 2015|language=Portuguese}} being substituted for [[Santi Mina]] in the 56th minute of an eventual 2–0 defeat.{{cite news|title=Zenit stay perfect at Valencia's expense|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015735/postmatch/report/index.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=24 November 2015}} He made his top-flight debut against Las Palmas on 28 August, replacing [[Enzo Pérez]] for the final four minutes of a 2–4 home loss.{{cite news|title=El Las Palmas desnuda al Valencia|trans-title=Las Palmas expose Valencia|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/deportes/las-palmas-desnuda-valencia-5339074|accessdate=19 September 2016|publisher=El Periódico|date=23 August 2016|language=Spanish}} Mir began the first half of the 2017–18 season for Valencia B in good form, scoring 15 goals in 19 games, attracting interest from [[Real Madrid]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11699/11194410/wolves-close-to-signing-rafa-mir-from-valencia|title=Wolves close to signing Rafa Mir from Valencia|publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 January 2018}} ===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 3 January 2018, Mir joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] for an undisclosed fee, signing a four-and-a-half-year contract with the club and taking the number 9 shirt.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180103-welcome-rafa/|title=Welcome Rafa|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers Football Club|date=3 January 2018}} He links up with former Valencia boss [[Nuno Espírito Santo]], who gave him his first team debut at the club. ====Las Palmas (loan)==== On 23 July 2018, Mir joined [[Segunda División]] side [[UD Las Palmas]] on loan for one season.{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180723-mir-departs-molineux-on-loan/|title=Mir Departs Molineux On Loan|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers FC|date=23 July 2018|access-date=23 July 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 6 January 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/rafael-mir-vicente/398451/|title=Rafa Mir Statistics|work=soccerway|accessdate=3 {{Infobox football biography | name = Donovan Wilson | image = | caption = | fullname = Donovan Junior Wilson{{cite web|title=Retained List 2016-17|url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-released-and-retained-list---2016-17.pdf|publisher=English Premier League|format=PDF|accessdate=13 June 2017}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|3|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Yate]], England | height = {{height|m=1.8}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = 200?–2004 | youthclubs1 = Bradley Stoke United | youthyears2 = 2004–2014 | youthclubs2 = [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] | years1 = 2014–2015 | clubs1 = [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014–2015 | clubs2 = → [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] (loan) | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2015– | clubs3 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps3 = 1 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4= → [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] (loan) | caps4 = 8 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5= → [[FC Jumilla|Jumilla]] (loan) | caps5 = 16 | goals5 = 6 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6= → [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] (loan) | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 0 | club-update = 24 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Donovan Junior Wilson''' (born 14 March 1997) is an English [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[ EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]], on loan from [[Premier League]] side [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. He joined Wolves from [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in January 2015 following a brief loan spell, and made his first-team debut in February 2017. He spent the second half of the 2017–18 season on loan at [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]]. He spent the first half of the 2018–19 season on loan at Spanish club [[FC Jumilla|Jumilla]] and joined Exeter City on loan for the second half of the season. ==Career== ===Bristol Rovers=== Wilson began his career at [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]], signing a one-year deal at the age of 17 in May 2014; he had spent ten years at the club's academy after signing from Bradley Stoke United at the age of seven.{{cite news| title=Donovan Wilson signs a pro-contract with Rovers|publisher=Bristol Rovers F.C| url=http://www.bristolrovers.co.uk/news/article/donovan-wilson-pro-contract-1565051.aspx|accessdate=12 January 2018| date=27 November 2014}} He made the bench at the [[Memorial Stadium (Bristol)|Memorial Stadium]] during the [[2014–15 Bristol Rovers F.C. season|2014–15]] [[National League (division)|Conference Premier]] promotion winning season, but did not make it onto the pitch for the "Pirates".{{Soccerway|donovan-wilson/368463}} Manager [[Darrell Clarke]] reportedly had planned to give him his debut in one match before realising he had already made his three allotted substitutions.{{cite news|title=Striker delighted to extend Wolves stay|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/academy/201634-next-generation-donovan-wilson/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=wolves.co.uk|date=4 March 2016|language=en}} ===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== Wilson initially joined [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in a loan deal in November 2014, before a permanent transfer for an undisclosed fee was finalised once the January transfer window opened.{{cite news| title=Wolves land Donovan Wilson permanently|publisher=Express & Star| url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2015/01/07/wolves-land-donovan-wilson-permanently/|accessdate=12 January 2018| date=7 January 2015}} He played three [[EFL Trophy]] matches for the [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. Development Squad and Academy|under-23 team]] in the [[2016–17 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2016–17]] season, and scored in the 4–0 win over [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]] at the [[Crown Ground]] on 8 November.{{cite news|title=Checkatrade Trophy (Sky Sports)|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/wolves-u21-vs-accrington/367385|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=SkySports|date=6 November 2016|language=en}} He signed a new 18-month contract in December 2016.{{cite news|title=New contracts for Wolves trio|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2016/12/22/new-contracts-for-wolves-trio/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Express and Star|date=22 December 2016|language=en}} He made his first-team debut for Wolves in the [[FA Cup]] on 18 February 2017, coming on as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Andreas Weimann]] in a 2–0 defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]].{{cite news| title=Wolves 0–2 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Sport| url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38940092|accessdate=12 January 2018| date=18 February 2017}} Manager [[Paul Lambert]] said that he had put Wilson on the bench because of his pace, though he remained behind fellow youngsters [[Bright Enobakhare]], [[Connor Ronan]] and [[Morgan Gibbs-White]] in the first-team pecking order.{{cite news|title=Donovan Wilson backed by Paul Lambert to succeed at Wolves|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/02/22/donovan-wilson-backed-by-paul-lambert-to-succeed-at-wolves/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Express and Star|date=22 February 2017|language=en}} Wilson made his [[EFL Championship]] debut on 14 April, coming on as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Jón Daði Böðvarsson]] in a 2–0 home defeat to [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].{{cite news|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 0-2 Brighton & Hove Albion|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39522687|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=BBC Sport|date=14 April 2017}} He scored his first senior goal on 23 August 2017, in a 2–0 victory over [[Premier League]] club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at [[St Mary's Stadium|St Mary's]] in the Second Round of the [[EFL Cup]].{{cite news| title=Southampton 0–2 Wolves|accessdate=12 January 2018|publisher=BBC Sport| url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40944673| date=23 August 2017}} He signed a new three-year contract two months later.{{cite news|last1=Judah|first1=Nathan|title=Wolves duo Donovan Wilson and Christian Herc sign new deals|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/10/31/wolves-duo-donovan-wilson-and-christian-herc-sign-new-deals/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Express and Star|date=31 October 2017|language=en}} On 11 January 2018, he joined [[EFL League Two]] side [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]] on loan until the end of the [[2017–18 Port Vale F.C. season|2017–18]] season.{{cite news|last1=Baggaley|first1=Michael|title=Port Vale sign striker Donovan Wilson on loan from Wolves|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/sport/football/port-vale-sign-striker-donovan-1042585|accessdate=11 January 2018|work=Stoke Sentinel|date=11 January 2018}} The "Valiants" had previously attempted to sign Wilson on loan the previous summer.{{cite news|last1=Spiers|first1=Tim|title=Wolves winger Jordan Graham joins Fulham on loan|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2017/08/31/wolves-winger-jordan-graham-joins-fulham-on-loan/|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Express and Star|date=31 August 2017|language=en}} Manager [[Neil Aspin]] said there had been competition from others clubs to sign the youngster.{{cite news|last1=Baggaley|first1=Michael|title=Port Vale boss delighted to see off rivals for Wolves striker Donovan Wilson|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/sport/football/port-vales-neil-aspin-delighted-1044798|accessdate=12 January 2018|work=Stoke Sentinel|date=11 January 2018}} On 17 March, Wilson scored his first goal in the [[English Football League]] in a 2–2 draw with [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage]] at [[Vale Park]].{{cite news|last1=Baggaley|first1=Michael|title=Comment as Port Vale edge towards safety and fans vent frustration at owner|url=https://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/sport/football/comment-port-vale-edge-towards-1353576|accessdate=18 March 2018|work=Stoke Sentinel|date=18 March 2018}} On 31 August 2018, Wilson joined [[Segunda División B]] club [[FC Jumilla|Jumilla]] on loan, along with eight Wolves teammates.{{cite news |title=Wolves send nine player on loan to FC Jumilla |url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/academy/20180831-wolves-send-nine-player-on-loan-to-fc-jumilla/ |accessdate=11 September 2018 |work=wolves.co.uk |date=31 August 2018 |language=en}} He scored six goals in 16 league games for the club and was praised by manager [[Leonel Pontes]].{{cite news |last1=Dicken |first1=Alex |title=Donovan Wilson scouting report: Wolves ace continues to excite in Spain |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/donovan-wilson-scouting-report-wolves-15284121 |accessdate=31 January 2019 |work=Birmingham Mail |date=15 October 2018}} Wilson said that "over here I’ve been playing game after game, and I’m pleased that I’m getting more minutes into my legs, getting me fitter, stronger, so it’s been a really good experience."{{cite news |last1=Spiers |first1=Tim |title=Donovan Wilson learning worldwide language of football |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2018/11/23/donovan-wilson-learning-worldwide-language-of-football/ |accessdate=31 January 2019 |work=Express and Star |date=23 November 2018 |language=en}} On 31 January 2019, he returned to England and joined League Two side [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on loan until the end of the [[2018–19 Exeter City F.C. season|2018–19]] season, replacing departing loanee striker [[Tristan Abrahams]].{{cite news |last1=Pilnick |first1=Brent |title=Donovan Wilson: Exeter City loan forward from Wolverhampton Wanderers
